About Today: SS. Cosmas and Damian, wonderworkers, unmercenary physicians, Martyrs. They were twins, Arabs by birth and lived in Cilicia. They are highly esteemed in the Eastern Church. (Confer Nov. 1.)

Day Name: Deposition of the Robe of the Theotokos
About Today: Deposition of the Venerable Robe of The Theotokos, in the church of Blachernae at Constantinople in the reign of the Emperor Leo and his consort Irene. — Our holy father, Juvenal, who, after St. Cyril was the third Patriarch of Jerusalem, died A.D. 454 during the reign of Marcian and Pulcheria, Emperors.

St. Hyacinth, Martyr, a chamberlain of the Emperor Trajan at Caesarea in Cappadocia. Accused of being a Christian, he was cruelly scourged and cast into prison and given no food except meat consecrated to idols. He lingered many days and died of hunger about A.D. 108. — Our holy father, Anatolius, Patriarch of Constantinople, who flourished A.D. 453 during the reign of the Emperor Marcian.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: Our holy father, Andrew, the Jerusalemite, Archbishop of Crete. He died A.D. 686, under the reign of Justinian II, Emperor. — Venerable Martha, mother of St. Simeon of the "Wondermount."
Remarks: Independence Day, optional texts, Heb 12:7-11,14-17,25-28; Jn 8:31-42.

Day Name: 6TH SUNDAY AFTER PENTECOST|Athanasius of Mount Athos—Venerable
About Today: Our venerable father, Athanasius, Hegumen-Abbot of Mt. Athos, A.D. 1805 — Venerable Lampadus, wonderworker of Irenopolis, and our venerable mother Martha, mother of the Holy Simeon of the "Wonderful Mountain."
Remarks: Feast of our Venerable Father Athanasius of Mt. Athos, Epistle, Galatians 5:22-6:2; Gospel, Luke 6:17-23.

About Today: Our venerable father, Sisoes the Great, Hermit and Anchorite in Egypt. He died about A.D. 429 after 62 years in the wilderness.

Our venerable fathers, Thomas of Malea and Acacius who is mentioned in "The Ladder of Perfection." — St. Cyriaca, Martyr, a wealthy Roman widow who sheltered persecuted Christians. Her charity cost her life. She was scourged to death as a Christian A.D. 249, under persecutor Decius, Emperor.

St. Procopius, Great-Martyr, a Palestinian Christian, a Lector and Interpreter in the Church of Scythopolis. Arrested in the persecution under Diocletian, he was brought to Caesarea, boldly confessed his Faith before judges, was sentenced and executed A.D. 303.

St. Pancratius, Priest-Martyr, Bishop of Taormina, was a disciple of St. Peter the Apostle, who sent him as a missionary Bishop into Sicily, where he laid down his life for Christ. — St. Theodore, Bishop of Edessa. — and The fasting Ten Thousand Saints.

Our venerable father, Anthony of the "Kiev-Cave," being the first of all the Monks of "Rus" to lead a monastic life during the sovereignty of Vladimir the Great, Grand Duke of "Rus." He died A.D. 1078 having spent 26 years in the cave, attaining to the advanced age of 90 years. — Forty-five Martyrs at Nicopolis in Armenia. Mauricius, Daniel, Antonius and others with them who suffered death under Licinius, Emperor, A.D. 317.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: St. Euphemia, Martyr, the most commendable, her knowledge was like that of the holy Fathers, suffered death A.D. 288. — The death of Blessed Olga, Grand Duchess of Kiev. In baptism (about A.D. 955) she chose the name "Helen."

SS. Proclus and Hilary, Martyrs, were Christians of Ancyra in Galatia (Asia Minor), tortured and put to death by Trajan and Maximum, Emperors A.D. 115. — Our venerable father, Michael of Malea flourished in the year A.D. 931. — St. Mary, Martyr, was the wife of a magician. Lived in the year A.D. 588 in the reign of Mauricius, Emperor.
Synaxis of St. Gabriel, the Archangel. (See March 26.) — Our venerable father Stephen of Sabbas, who suffered death during the reign of Severus, Emperor, A.D. 201.
St. Aquila, Apostle, died A.D. 65. — Onesimus, venerable.

Day Name: Vladimir the Great—Equal to the Apostles
About Today: St. Vladimir the Great, Equal to the Apostles, Grand-Duke of "Rus" took the name "Basil" at his baptism, A.D. 988, thus enlightening the realm of "Rus" in the reign of the Greek Emperor Basil II. He died A.D. 1015 after an edifying and penitent life, and was laid to rest in the church which he built in Kiev by his tithes in honor of the Blessed Mother of God. — SS. Kirykos, and his mother, Julitta, Martyrs, died A.D. 296 during the reign of the Emperor Diocletian.

SS. Athenogenes, Priest-Martyr, Bishop of Sebaste (Armenia) with ten of his Flock who were put to death A.D. 302 during the great persecution under Diocletian and his colleagues. Fathers of the Six Ecumenical Councils.
The holy great-martyr Marina at Antioch, (270). Our venerable father and confessor Paul Gojdich, bishop of Preshov, who defended the Byzantine Catholic Church A.D. (1960).
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: SS. Hyacinth and Emilian, Martyrs, Hyacinth of Amastris in Paphlagonia, died in prison of wounds received from torture. Emilian was a Christian of Dorostrium on the Danube (Silistria). He was burned to death under Emperor Julian the Apostate A.D. 362.

Day Name: SUNDAY OF THE FATHERS OF THE SIX ECUMENICAL COUNCILS
About Today: Our venerable mother, Macrina, sister of St. Basil, at an early age, in the reign of Emperor Gratianus, consecrated herself to the service of God. She helped to educate her brothers, was instrumental in founding several Religious Houses and presided as Hegumena-Abbess over one of these. She died in the same year as her brother St. Basil the Great, A.D. 379 and was buried in the grave of her mother, St. Emellia in the church of the Forty Martyrs in Caesarea. — Our venerable father, Dius, flourished during the reign of Theodosius the Great, Emperor.
Remarks: Eighth Sunday after Pentecost and Commemoration of the Fathers at the first Six Ecumenical Councils. On Mt. St. Macrina, patronal feast.

About Today: Saint Elijah of Thesbite, Glorious Prophet, about 850 B.C., raised up in the Kingdom of Israel of the stock of Aaron, to reprove the ten fallen Tribes.

Our venerable father, Simeon, surnamed Salus (fool) and John, his co-faster, Hermits. Simeon lived as a hermit in a desert for nearly thirty years near the Red Sea, but afterwards at Emesus in Syria. — St. Ezekiel, the Third of the Four Greater Prophets and writer of a canonical Book of Scriptures. Tradition says he was put to death while in captivity in Babylon by one of the Jewish Headmen turned pagan, 525 B.C.

St. Mary Magdalene, myrrh-bearer and Equal to the Apostles. According to Catholic view, she is one and the same with Mary the Sinner, Mary of Bethany, the sister of Lazarus and Martha, the Magdalen at the foot of the Cross and at the Tomb and the first witness to the Resurrection. — Return of the Relics of St. Phocas, Priest-Martyr, a Bishop of Sinope. His relics were translated to Vienne in France in the 13th century. (Confer September 22.)

SS. Trophimus, Theophilus and others with them, suffered martyrdom by beheading about A.D. 302 during the reign of Diocletian, Emperor. — St. Apollynaris, Priest-Martyr appointed first Bishop of Ravenna by St. Peter, died in the reign of Vespasian, Emperor A.D. 79.
Remarks: The Feast Day of our Blessed Father and Confessor Basil (Hopko) is May 11, but it may be observed today, the day of his passing.

About Today: SS. Boris and Gleb, Martyrs, in their baptism had taken the names of Romanus and David, were Princes, sons of St Vladimir, the first Christian Grand Duke of "Rus." They died A.D. 1010. — St. Christina, Martyr, was tortured and put to death at Lucas Vulsinus in Tuscany, Italy, A.D. 200 during the reign of Septimius Severus, Emperor.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance.

About Today: Dormition of St. Anna, Mother of the Blessed Virgin Mary Mother of God. (Confer Dec. 8.)
SS. Hermolaus, Priest-Martyr and two brothers, Hermippas and Thermocrates, martyred about 300 A.D. in Nicomedia the residence of the Emperor Diocletian. — St. Parasceva Venerable-Martyr.

Pantaleon or Panteleimon, the Great Martyr and Imperial physician, reckoned with St. Luke, Apostle. Patron of medical men. He suffered death by beheading about A.D. 303 during the reign of Maximian, Emperor. — Our venerable mother Anthusa, mother of St. John Chrysostom. — St. Clement of Ochrid — wonderworker.

SS. Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon and Parmenas, Apostles and Deacons, four of the Seven Deacons spoken of in the Acts 6:5 all having suffered death for Christ. — Our holy father, Innocentius Pope of Rome. After many hardships he died A.D. 417.

St. Callinicus, Martyr at Gangrae about A.D. 290. — SS. Seraphina, Virgin-Martyr, Theodotia and her Children, of Syrian origin, adopted daughter of St. Sabina whom she had converted to Christianity at Rome, arrested and beheaded A.D. 122.

SS. Silas, Silvanus, Criscentus, Hepenetus and Andronicus, Apostles. — St. John, soldier-Martyr, endured death in Caesarea of Cappadocia during the reign of Constantine and Galerius. — St. Julitta, Martyr.
St. Eudocimus, Venerable, lived in the reign of the Iconoclast Emperor Theophilus.
Remarks: Simple abstinence from meat or equivalent penance. Pre-festive Day of the Procession of the Holy Cross.
